quotes.text: Uh, hello. Uh, this is Dwight Schrute calling for Jan Levenson-Gould.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Hi. Dwight Schrute calling, acting manager, Scranton branch. Listen, I needed your permission to fire Jim Halpert.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Dwight Schrute.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Well…

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: He is not here right now. He put me in charge of the office.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: That’s not entirely true, because he put me in charge of picking the health care plan.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Yeah.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Call you immediately. Good. Oh, hey, listen, um, since I have you on the phone, um, can I fire Jim?

quotes.text: Oh, this is your cell, I thought this was your… [dial tone]

quotes.speaker: Dwight

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: I tried being rational, OK? And what happened? The employees went crazy, I got no help from corporate. That leaves me with no options.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: I’m now going to read out loud your submitted medical conditions. When you hear yours read, please raise your hand to indicate that it is real. If you do not raise your hand, it will not be covered.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: You know what? You have forfeited that privilege. I have tried to treat you all as adults, but obviously I am the only adult here. Number one, inverted penis.

quotes.text: I thought your vagina was removed during your hysterectomy?

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: OK, great. Dermatitis. Thank you Angela. I’ll make sure that’s covered. OK, now. Who wrote this, hysterical one? Anal fissures?

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Yeah, but no one here has it.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: I most certainly did not.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Oh, um… Jan wants you to call her.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: [heated discussion in the ‘Dwight Schrute Workspace’, door opens] I did not dismiss you.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: You came into my office voluntarily.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Well, maybe they won’t get slashed if you answer all my questions.

quotes.text: You know when ever a worker is promoted above their peers there’s always going to be a little bit of jealousy. Uh, it’s natural. And that’s going to lead to goofing off and that’s okay that’s fine. As long as they are willing to suffer the consequences.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Psssh, no.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Yeah. Well, have you ever seen the movie Unbreakable? ‘Cause that guy couldn’t get sick, just like me.

quotes.text: I don’t think so, no.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Wrong. [walks away] Thank you Jim. Kevin. Stanley. [whispering] Pam, Jim, Kevin, Stanley. Pam, Jim, Kevin, Stanley. You finished?

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Why do you want health care, Pam? Hmm? Why do you want it?

quotes.text: But you’re engaged. Aren’t you and maybe you’ve set a date for the wedding, hmm? And because you know you’re going to get married you don’t have to take our health care plan seriously.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: You really expect me to believe you haven’t set a date? I think you have. Sure Pam, sure. But you know what, you’ve been engaged for three years and I know you’ve set a date. And you know what else, I know you’ve got coverage under Roy and I know that you wrote down those fake diseases. Admit it. Admit it, Pam.

quotes.text: You wrote down… I didn’t give you permission to.. I didn’t…

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: You’re doing the right thing. Go ahead. What ‘s your confession?

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Let it out.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Okay. You wanna do this the hard way. We’ll do this the hard way. You wrote down those fake diseases didn’t you?

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: I know you did.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Well, because I want to know who wrote those diseases down.

quotes.speaker: Dwight

quotes.speaker: Dwight

quotes.text: One word.

quotes.text: Michael!?

quotes.text: Yeah, so I don’t have to worry?

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Bottom line. Do I need to be worried?

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: It’s a real shame, ’cause studies have shown that more information gets passed through water-cooler gossip than through official memos. Which puts me at a disadvantage, because I bring my own water to work.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: I didn’t do it. What do you mean? Oh, the water cooler was brought over here for… maintenance. So what do you guys hear? What’s the scuttlebutt?

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Hey, so listen, I was thinking that it might be a good idea if you and I formed an alliance. ‘Cause of the downsizing? I think an alliance might be a good idea, you know. Help each other out.

quotes.text: Do you want to form, an alliance, with me?

quotes.text: The gun show. [Rolls up his sleeve and kisses his bicep]

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Jim! Hey. Hi, Pam. Listen, could I talk to you a second about the… paper products?

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Did you tell Pam about the alliance?

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Just now.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Right, that’s good, good, pursue this.

quotes.text: Mmm hmm.

quotes.text: They seem awfully chummy, don’t you think?

quotes.text: Only one way to find out.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: What? I believe it.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: I could tell, from the body language.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Good, let ’em. It helps our cause.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Oh, they’re forming an alliance

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Damn it. God!

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: God… Damn it! Why us?

quotes.text: Jackpot.

quotes.text: I don’t think she’d be missed.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: That’s where they remove the uterus.

quotes.text: Oh my God, we have to be there.

quotes.text: No no, yes there is. Behind the shelves. Oh my God.

quotes.text: I know. I know exactly what to do.

quotes.text: I’m a deer hunter. I go all the time with my dad. One thing about deer, they have very good vision. One thing about me, I am better at hiding than they are… at vision.

quotes.text: This is going to be perfect, OK? Centrally located. Perfect cover. I can hear and see everything.

quotes.text: Look, I can breathe just fine. OK, but if it makes you feel better, I’ll poke holes in the box.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Can I trust Jim? I don’t know. Do I have a choice? No, frankly, I don’t. Will I trust Jim? Yes. Should I trust Jim? You tell me.

quotes.text: [With blonde hair] That’s politics baby. Get what you can out of someone, then crush them. I think Jim might have learned a very valuable lesson.

quotes.text: Pssh, stupid. Identity theft happens all the time. I can become you like that. [snaps fingers] But no one can become me.

quotes.text: Isn’t that crazy? I’m a Volunteer Sheriff’s Deputy. Lackawanna County says that it’s okay for me to perform CPR, but for Michael my lips aren’t qualified enough for his perfect little face. It’s nuts.

quotes.text: The purse girl hits everything on my checklist. Creamy skin. Straight teeth. Curly hair. Amazing breasts. Not for me, for my children. The Schrutes produce very thirsty babies.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Hey, how’s it going?  Good. Can I talk to you for a second? In private?

quotes.text: Just for a minute.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Please? I wanted to talk to you in private because I wanted to ask you out on a date.

quotes.text: Ok was that no to talking to me in private, or was that no to the date?

quotes.text: The perfect girl for me would be Konikotaka. She has the most amazing story. She was orphaned at age 10 when both her parents were assassinated, and she was taken in by a wealthy, but very cruel, businessman. So she practiced aikido in secret for years until she could avenge the death of her parents. She’s also a survivor of monster rape.

quotes.text: This is really well made. Good stitching. Excellent fabric. [shakes the purse from side to side by it’s handle] You sell a lot of these?

quotes.text: Let me describe the perfect date. I take her out to a nice dinner. She looks amazing. Some guy tries to hit on her. Uh, now he wants to fight. So I grab him. I throw him into a jukebox. Then the other ninja’s got a knife. He comes at me. We grapple. I turn his knife on him. Blood on the dance floor. She’s scared now, I take her home. I’m holding her in my arms. I reach in for a kiss. I hear something in the leaves. I flip her around. She gets a poison arrow right in her back. She was in on it the whole time. But, I knew.

quotes.text: Excuse me, everyone, could I have your attention please. I just wanted to say that the women in this office are terrible. Especially the ones who wrote that stuff about Michael on the bathroom wall. Having a bathroom is a privilege. It is called a ladies room for a reason. And if you cannot behave like ladies, well then you are not going to have a bathroom.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: [bangs fists] Blood alone moves the wheels of history! Have you ever asked yourselves in an hour of meditation, which everyone finds during the day. [waves arm] how long we have been striving for greatness? [bangs fist] Not only the years we’ve been at war, the war of work, but from the moment as a child when we realized that the world could be conquered. It has been a lifetime’s struggle [waves arms]. A never-ending fight. I say to you [hits podium] and you’ll understand that it is a privilege to fight!

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: WE ARE WARRIORS!

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Salesman of Northeastern Pennsylvania, I ask you once more rise and be worthy of this historical hour!

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: [laughs maniacally] Yeah. Yes!

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: No revolution is worth anything unless it can defend itself. [bangs fists]

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Some people will tell you salesman is a bad word. They’ll conjure up images of used car dealers and door to door charlatans. This is our duty – to change their perception. I say salesmen… and women of the world unite! We must never acquiesce for it is together, TOGETHER, THAT WE PREVAIL!  We must never cede control of the motherland! For it is…

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Ok, thanks. [to Michael] There you are. What happened?

quotes.text: And what a lot of people don’t understand about sales is that it has so much to do with organization. I have a system in place for keeping track of who I speak to, when I speak to them and what we have discussed. Etcetera.

And now, a very special treat… a book my Grandmutter used to read me when I was a kid.  This is a very special story, it’s called Struwwelpeter, by Heinrich Hoffman from 1864. [reading from book] The great tall tailor always comes to little girls that suck their thumbs— are you listening, Sasha? Right? And ‘ere they dream when he’s about, he takes his great sharp scissors out, and then cuts their thumbs clean off!

quotes.text: [employees chuckle] And he is on TV now!

quotes.text: Uh, okay. But first, that’s not my name.

quotes.text: Well at least I’m not a horrible little latchkey kid who got suspended from school. So…

quotes.text: And they do, your parents, love you very much.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: The Schrutes consider children very valuable. In the olden days, the women would bear many children, so we would have enough laborers to work the fields. And if it was an especially cold winter, and there weren’t enough grains or vegetables, they would eat the weakest of the brood. [Laughs] They didn’t eat the children.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: What the… [pulls a pencil eraser out of his mug, after a drink]

quotes.text: Oh, I hate to break it to you, Abby. The certificate’s a fake. Okay? It’s not real. Where’s the certification number, Halpert?

quotes.text: Ebay. Hm. Question! May I be in charge of the party planning festivities?

quotes.text: Uh, that’s a list price of four dollars and fifty cents.  Unfortunately, this item is on [watch beeps] back… order… [hangs up] Michael! Michael! Michael Michael Michael! Come here, come here, come here!  Come here!

quotes.text: Listen up everyone! It is 11:23 exactly, the exact moment when you emerged from your mother’s vaginal canal, so… huh?! Right, have a seat. Please.

quotes.text: There is a tradition that the Hebrews have of hoisting the birthday boy up on a chair.

quotes.text: Why tip someone for a job I’m capable of doing myself? I can deliver food. I can drive a taxi. I can, and do, cut my own hair. I did, however, tip my urologist, because… I am unable to pulverize my own kidney stones.

quotes.text: [whispering] But what if i’m hungry?

quotes.text: Michael’s birthday is hard for me because he gets very excited. But he’s also under a lot of pressure, which builds up until he’s ready to explode. As his right-hand man, it’s my job to release that pressure so that he can enjoy himself, if only for a moment.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: To think that a man’s skin could turn on him. It’s brilliant, ’cause you’d never expect it. Most people think of their skin as an ally. [scoffs] Makes me rethink having skin at all.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Kevin Malone, you’re next. Spit that out. [Kevin shoves the rest of the donut he’s eating into his mouth] Spit… Okay, come on, let’s go.

quotes.text: Thanks, girl.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Let’s go over some of the symptoms of marijuana use, shall we?  You tell me who this sounds like: slow moving, inattentive, dull, constantly snacking, shows a lack of motivation.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: I like the people I work with generally, with four exceptions.  But someone committed a crime and I did not become a Lackawanna County Volunteer Sheriff’s deputy to make friends. And by the way, I haven’t.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Stop! This is not Kelly Kapoor story hour.  Illegal drugs were consumed on company property, okay? Your ass is on the line, mister!  My ass is is on the line!  Now I’m going to ask you again.  What time did you go home last night?

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: I didn’t know that you were at a party on Saturday night.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Okay, I’m gonna need to search your car.  Give me you keys.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Don’t make me do this the hard way.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: I go down to the police station on my lunch break. I tell a police officer, I know several, what I suspect you may have in your car. He requests a hearing from a judge and obtains a search warrant, once he has said warrant, he will drive over here, and make you give him the keys to your car, and you will have to obey him.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: I can’t stop this investigation. It is my job.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: I volunteered for this job.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: It is my duty…

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: …to investigate the crime scene. I have six more interviews to go and then I will reveal what I know.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: If you are attempting to compliment me then you have done a very good job.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Well, you have…

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: …because being a narc is one of the hardest jobs that you can have…

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: …and I am very proud of being a narc.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Oscar visited Mexico when he was five to attend his great-grandmother’s funeral. What does that mean to a United States law enforcement officer? He’s a potential drug mule.

quotes.text: Have you ever taken any illegal drugs?

quotes.text: Have you ever… pooped… a balloon?

quotes.text: He sure left in a hurry.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: I don’t want to blow this. This is what all good law enforcement officers dream of. The chance to solve an actual crime.

quotes.text: [opens eyes wide in total surprise]

quotes.text: Where were you yesterday after work?

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Attention everyone.  Drug testers are coming in a couple of hours to test everyone’s urine.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Company policy. If drugs are found on the premises there is automatic drug testing conducted within twenty-four hours.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: No you can’t do that.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: No you cannot. It has to be official, and it has to be urine.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: No, you will be tested.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: You will be. That is the law according to the rules.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Hi, Linda. Dwight Schrute, Assistant Regional Manager. You might remember testing my urine a few years back when I was applying to be a volunteer sheriff’s deputy.

quotes.text: Mine was green.

quotes.text: I’m all better.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Then I refuse.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Are you serious?

quotes.text: But that’s illegal.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Not my urine.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Were you forced to do drugs at this concert?

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: I want him to have all the urine he needs.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: I know that. Don’t you think I know that?

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: My father’s name was Dwight Schrute. My grandfather’s name was Dwight Schrute. His father’s name Dwide Schrude. Amish. I loved my father very much. Every morning he’d wake up at dawn and make us biscuits with gravy. When I was little my dad and I played a lot of games together. My dad cheated a lot but I never busted him on it. I would have, except I didn’t know about it. He didn’t tell me till years later. I was shocked when I found out.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: That’s great.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: It’s a uniform and I turned it in today when I tendered my resignation.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: I took an oath when I was sworn in and I broke that oath today.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Really?

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: That’s fantastic because I’ve always felt that the security here sucked .

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Thank you, Michael. Very nice. Great. [To Hank]  Can I have a gun?

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Okay, I’ll have to bring in my bow staff.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: [salutes] Thank you, Michael.

quotes.text: I need to go over some details with you.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: First of all, Hank, how many orange traffic cones do you have?

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Oh, God.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: I’m not only hoping to find the culprit who committed this heinous crime, I am praying to find this heinous culprit. And I will pray to Thor himself, if that’s what it takes.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: People use marijuana to escape. Jim does not have a girlfriend. His sales are nothing to brag about. And he does not belong to any organized clubs. If that were my life, I’d do drugs.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Your turn, Stanley. [Stanley just takes a drink from his mug] Angela, you’re up.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Go ahead. Don’t lie.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: No, no, no. It’s okay. Go ahead.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Oh.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Oh.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Kelly Kapour. Say your prayers. Let’s go. Conference room, pronto. Come on, step it up.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Oh, me? Just one of the gang. Sitting in the back, doodling, not playing attention. Bam! Pow! Surprise! Got you! [Note pad reads, “Creed -Shifty eyes / Ryan – Dilated pupils / Kelly – Hyperactive”] There’s a Volunteer Sheriff’s Deputy in your midst, and he is taking names.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Make-up sex. Nice!

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: The scary thing is, it could have been any one of these people. They all had a motive. To get high.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: just drink a lot of water.

quotes.text: You have to relax your muscles around the bladder.

quotes.text: Hey. Hey. Jerry.

quotes.text: Sheriff Pierce? I’m turning in my badge.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: I got it here.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: No, I mean at the gift shop. Also, I can’t wear this anymore.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Oh, don’t worry. I never abused my power. I only tried to help the Sheriff’s Department in any way I could.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Oh, God, there are so many. Roadside assistance, breaking up unruly parties, surveillance…

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Crowd control, directing traffic…

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: I’ve only had to use it once.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Oh! What is on your face? Is that a disguise?

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Clown paint.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: I.D. badges are long overdue. Security in this office park is a joke. Last year, I came to work with my spud gun in a duffel bag. I sat at my desk all day, with a rifle that shoots potatoes at 60 pounds per square inch. Can you imagine if I was deranged?

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Oh, he’s sure. Just shoot.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Whoa.. wha… wait. If someone has a problem with me, why would they withdraw it six months ago?

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: That is not true. Redact it. Redact it!

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Okay, question. [looks at Toby] When a name is withdrawn, does that also apply to the permanent misbehavior file in New York?

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: That doesn’t make any sense.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: No.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: I never smile if I can help it. Showing one’s teeth is a submission signal in primates. When someone smiles at me, all I see is a chimpanzee begging for its life.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: This is humongous. I am not a security threat…

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: And my middle name is ‘Kurt’, not ‘Fart’.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: I have another complaint for Jim’s permanent file.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: What box?!

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Ah… agh… dgh… Ahh! No, no! Four years of malfeasance unreported. This cannot stand.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: No! You calm down! Who’s side is Toby on? Who’s side are you on?

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Him or me?

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Him or me? I cannot work with Jim anymore.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Either he goes, or I go.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: You choose!

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: One of us is out of here by the end of today! [runs out]

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: I am not bluffing!

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Okay?

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Do the right thing here, Michael. Okay, I have served you loyally for years.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: I deserve this. You know I do!

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: You have till five.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Oh, look, Jim. There’s a sales manager position open in Stamford. Want me to call Jan and tell her you’re interested? I could put in a good word for you, ’cause I’ll still be working here. Transfer! Transfer! Everybody! Transfer! Transfer! Transfer! Transfer!

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: It’s a good market. Higher volume.

quotes.text: I don’t believe that Jim moved that coat rack. But if he did, he has an obligation to use his gift wisely. With great power comes great responsibility. They could do a cross-section of his brain to find out more. But I don’t think it’s true, though.

It’s really what’s best for the branch.  And I could care less about my co-workers.  So [cutting his food, giving Jan a “so there” look], here we are.  It’s all, on the table.  I want… the branch.  And I await your decision.

quotes.text: [looks to Angela]

quotes.text: The Schrutes are a very loyal breed. But I also have Mannheim blood from my German grandmother. And the Mannheims knew when to cut and run. No sense going down with a losing regime. But the Schrute blood… It’s amazing that when these two bloods mix, the whole thing didn’t explode.

quotes.text: [laughs uproariously and applauds] Whoo!

quotes.text: Okay. [continues to laugh] Whoo!

quotes.text: If my head ever comes off, I would like you to put it on ice.

quotes.text: When I die, I wanna be frozen. And if they have to freeze me in pieces, so be it.  I will wake up stronger than ever because I will have used that time to figure out exactly why I died and what moves I could have used to defend myself better now that I know what hold he had me in.

quotes.text: That is not a statue, that is a robot.

quotes.text: [grabbing ball] I got it.  When my mother was pregnant with me, they did an ultrasound and found she was having twins.  When they did another ultrasound a few weeks later, they discovered, that I had resorbed the other fetus.  Do I regret this?  No.  I believe his tissue has made me stronger.  I now have the strength of a grown man and a little baby.

quotes.text: I need a box.  I need a box.  A small box… not too confining.

quotes.text: Attention, everyone. As you know, Ed Truck is dead. If you have any contact information on Rolodex files or in Microsoft Outlook, remove it now. Also, if you have any photographs, Pam will make her shredder available during lunch. That is all.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Remembering the dead doesn’t help anybody. The way to best honor them is to figure out what killed them and prevent that thing from killing anyone ever again. In this case, some sort of steel exoskeleton to protect the neck, or else a device that allows the head to live separately from the body. I’m working on both.

quotes.text: Michael, no need to call corporate. We are supposed to use Toby. He’s trained as a grief counselor.

quotes.text: Brain teaser. I have two coins totaling 15 cents and one of them is not a nickel. What are they?

quotes.text: Ok. A man and his son get into a car accident. They are rushed to the hospital. The doctor says, there is no way I can operate on this boy, …

quotes.text: I am very excited. Ryan hasn’t made a sale yet, but more importantly, he hasn’t made an ally yet. Is he going to be a slacker-loser-wise-ass like Jim was? Or is he going to join the Dwight Army of Champions?

quotes.text: When you are ready to see the sales office, the sales office will present itself to you. Your journey begins now.

quotes.speaker: Dwight

quotes.text: It’s called bull crap and a client can smell it from a mile away.

quotes.text: Oh hey, I forgot something in my car.  I’ll be right back.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Congratulations resourceful salesman. You have passed the second challenge. Welcome to Schrute Farm.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: It is time for your next test. You have planted the beet seed. You have walked the long lonely walk of loneliness.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: You know what your problem is? You know why you haven’t made any sales? Cause you think you know everything. You have to trust that maybe there are other people that can teach you things. Are you ready to learn? Are you ready for the final test?

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Come on!

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Please be seated. [man runs behind Dwight]

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Pay no attention to the spirits that haunt this hallowed ground.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Yes.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Mose is my cousin and he lives here. He will always be my best friend. Unless things go well with Ryan today in which case, I won’t hang out with Mose so much anymore.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: What is the greatest danger facing Dunder Mifflin?

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Wrong. Flash floods. What is the true cause of Robert Mifflin’s suicide?

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Wrong. He hated himself. What is the DHARMA initiative?

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Final question, young Ryan Howard. What is Michael Scott’s greatest fear?

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Wrong. He’s not afraid of anything. Also, I would have accepted snakes. Fear is what it’s all about. You cannot sell while undergoing fear. You need to vanquish fear! One must wrestle fear to the ground. You will now wrestle my cousin Mose.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Wrestle him to the ground.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Ryan. Don’t. Ryan! You don’t have to wrestle him. Just get in the coffin. Ryan?

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Where are all the animals?

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Ryan, come on. I am sorry. I am sorry. Mose is sorry too. Look, he sent over a basket with eggs and some fat back bacon. And look, something he whittled.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: You still mad? It’s just Jim and I didn’t get along, and I didn’t want it to be that way again. You know, I wanted us to be a team. An unstoppable team that competed against other teams.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Screwgun. The sales call!

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Establish time frames. Keep the phrase “real dollars” in their head. And always keep the power in the conversation. That’s why you’re losing them on the cold calls. Cause you say the word please too much.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Michael always said, K.I.S.S. Keep it simple, stupid. Great advice, hurts my feelings every time.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Good.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Right.

quotes.text: Uh huh.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Exactly. Yes.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: They did not. They didn’t have to say it to your face.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Not everything’s a lesson, Ryan. Sometimes you just fail. It’s those online paper jerks. The whole business is changing. You know what? They’re going to be screwed once this whole internet fad is over. What are you doing? [Ryan throws egg at building] Oh no no no no! Ryan! Yes! Ryan the temp! Come on! Courtesy of Dunder Mifflin. Come on! Drive.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: [Dwight chokes as Ryan downs a beer in one drink] Temp! Temp! Temp! Temp! Ryan! Ryan! Ryan! Ryan! Yes! Just think, that temp agency could have sent you anywhere.

quotes.text: Take a good look at this boy…

quotes.speaker: Dwight

quotes.text: Today is Ryan’s first sales call and I am bringing this boy home a full-grown man.

quotes.text: I once saw a movie called “Training Day”. It starred an African-American and Ethan Hawke. In it, the African-American trains Ethan Hawke with various tests and trials. Today, Ryan is Ethan Hawke, and I am the African-American.

quotes.text: Get in the car.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: No, but seriously, your ears are the key. 90% of a good sales call is listening, only 10% is talking.

quotes.speaker: Dwight

quotes.text: Thank you very much. [hangs up cell phone] Okay, secretary says Wallace is away for the day and won’t be coming back into the office.

quotes.text: : Stranford is closed! Michael, we’re not closed. Stamford is closed. Stamford is closed.

quotes.text: The Japanese camp guards of World War II always chose one man to kill whenever a batch of new prisoners arrived. I always wondered how they chose the man who was to die. I think I would have been good at choosing the person.

quotes.text: On three. One… two… three.

quotes.text: He was already dead. And we Schrutes use every part of the goose. The meat has a delicious, smoky, rich flavor. Plus you can use the molten goose grease and save it in the refrigerator, thus saving you a trip to the store for a can of expensive goose grease.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Oh, look at this, she saved you two thousand dollars ’cause they failed to report a mold problem. [Continues to sift through papers] But wouldn’t that affect the final… How did she? Oh, oh, I see what she did. That is good. Wow. Carol is one smart cookie.

quotes.text: Pam and Karen. I am ordering you to cease and desist all party planning. Immediately.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: [from across the table] Where’s Michael going? Michael? Is he sick? Is he choking?

dwight.summary: Dwight is unofficially the assistant (to the) regional manager at Dunder Mifflin. Dwight is extremely passionate about paper and is constantly trying to impress Michael. Dwight is also the leading salesman in the Scranton office.
dwight.name: Dwight Schrute

quotes.text: No, no, no, Michael, listen OK. Don’t panic. We haven’t made… We haven’t decided.

quotes.text: I’ve spoken to Josh in Stamford. I’ve told him the same as you and it’s up to either him or you to convince me that your branch can incorporate the other.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: This does, however, mean that there is going to be downsizing.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Go ahead.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: So do you think we could keep a lid on this for now? I don’t want to worry people unnecessarily.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: So, which health plan have you decided on?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Wait, acupuncture? None of the plans have acupuncture. Have you looked at them closely Michael?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: The Gold Plan? I’m not even on that plan.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Michael.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: You know the whole reason that we’re doing this, is to save money. So you just need to pick a provider and choose the cheapest plan.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: It’s your job. So…

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Michael… maybe… I mean…

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Sometimes a manager, like yourself, has to deliver the bad news to the employees. I do it all the time.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: I’m doing it right now. To you.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Hello?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: This is Jan.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Who is this?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: From sales?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Where’s Michael Scott?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Dwight, listen to me very carefully. You are not a manager of anything. Understand?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Really?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: OK, when Michael gets back, you tell him to call me immediately.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: No. Please don’t use my cell phone ever again.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Are you listening to me Michael?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: What did I just say?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Alan and I have created an incentive program to increase sales.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: I’m not going to do that Michael.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: We’ve created an incentive program to increase sales.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: At the end of the month you can reward your top seller with a prize worth up to a thousand dollars.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Uh, yes. Yes you can.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: No, Michael. No. You can’t win this prize.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: [on speaker phone] It’s a, it’s, it’s a two and a half hour drive from New York, Michael.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: No.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: No, we don’t approve of this Michael. I mean, y-you only had the budget for one office party a year, so… we’re not paying for this.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Are you there Michael?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Really? I’m dropping an atomic bomb on you?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: You already had a party on May 5th for no reason.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: And you had a luau….

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: And a tsunami relief fundraiser which somehow lost a lot of money.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Okay, well, I don’t understand why anyone would have a tsunami FUN raiser, Michael. I mean, that doesn’t even make sense.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: [to cell phone] Yes. Yes, I did. Okay. Well, we can talk about that later then. [to Pam] Hi.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: You seem a little bit agitated, Michael. What’s the problem?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Well, that… that’s true in a way. You can’t say anything.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Do you need to see the video again, Michael?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Michael. MICHAEL!

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Michael, please.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Mike… Michael. Please. I… I… really.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: That’s not my sense of humor.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Wha…

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: [to Albiny] ‘Scuse me, I’m sorry. [to Michael] Michael. Mr. O’Malley is your lawyer.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Mr. O’Malley is our Corporate lawyer. We have him on retainer. To protect the company as well as upper level management, such as yourself.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: [on the phone] This is Jan.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Excuse me?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Devon. The… Oh, is this the man that you…

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: The person that you fired, Michael?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Is that what you’re… Okay. Oh, you sound a little… A little upset.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Well, I have to say that I am impressed, Michael. I know… I know how hard that was.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Well, I’m glad you did it, Michael.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: And so, good job. Good job.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Yeah. Good job.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: [talking over Michael] Yup. Yes.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: This is a projection of the county’s needs…

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Thirteen schools, uh, two hospitals…

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: So when we get to the Radisson, I’d like to, um-

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Excuse me?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: You had no right to do that, Michael.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: It said that.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Alright.  But you will let me run this meeting.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: What?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Thank you.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Michael, shouldn’t take more than an hour.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Do you always shut down the entire office when you leave for an hour?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: So which way is Chili’s?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Oh, no, that’s alright.  I wanna leave straight from there.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: I know Scranton.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Alright.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: If it’s a couple blocks away-

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Ok.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Why would we need a signal?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: What kinda trouble are you planning on getting in, Michael?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: You’re gonna let me do the talking, we agreed on that.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Just Jan Levinson.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: No. [To Christian] Thank you very much for meeting with us.  Have you been waiting long?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Michael.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Michael, we got divorced, ok? [to Christian] I’m so sorry.  Excuse me.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Michael. [to hostess] Uh, could we have a table for three, please?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: We’re in a meeting.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Christian.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: I thought we could start by going over the needs of the county.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: What?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: So-

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: If you have a-

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Christian, you don’t have to listen to this.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Just the one.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: [to waitress]  Excuse me, could I have a vodka tonic, please?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: We would probably be upset with ourselves if we went this whole night without talking business, so, Dunder-Mifflin can provide a level of personal service to the county that the warehouse chains just can’t match.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: What’s the bottom line?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: I don’t think Christian has time for that.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Oh no, Michael, Michael, please.  No, really.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: We’d been fighting for a while-

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: He didn’t want kids, but I knew that going into it.  But he also knew that I did.  I guess I thought that he would change his mind; he thought that I would change mine.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: I was stupid.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Uh- [Michael signals for her to shh]

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Bye… thanks. [pumps fist] Yes!

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: We got it!

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: I am really- [Michael kisses Jan] Thrilled. [Michael and Jan kiss again] Let’s go.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Let’s go.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: I’m almost there, so we should have plenty of time to go over the presentation.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: And, uh, hmm, excuse me, I’ve also confirmed the meeting this afternoon at four p.m.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: What?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: What do you mean?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Michael.  I need you to take this seriously.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Michael-

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Are you hearing me?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: This is a very important-

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: [sighs] I’ll see you in ten minutes.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Michael.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: I am returning your many calls.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: No. No, we won’t be discussing that, Michael.  The only things I wanna talk about during your performance review are your concrete ideas to improve your branch.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Uh, your review is anything but a formality, Michael.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: I expect you to forget anything that you think may have happened between us and exhibit completely professional behavior.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Ok, that is an example of completely unprofessional behavior.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Michael.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Are the cameras with you…

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: …in your office?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: [on phone]  We’ll address this in the meeting then. Ok. Ok, bye-bye. [to Pam]  Could you please tell Michael that I’m here?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: I’m good; how are you?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Nice to see you.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Can we please go in your office?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Thank you.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Nice to see you too, Michael.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Not like that.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: You know Michael, I think I need to make something clear right off the top.  I’m not going to discuss anything with you other than Dunder-Mifflin business.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Period.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Do we understand each other.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: So are you still in the middle of the performance reviews then?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: No.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Fine.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: How is that a business question?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Please don’t smell me, Michael.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Uh, I’d like to sit in on that meeting [to Pam] is it happening right now?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Great.  Very good.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: I can’t, I can’t-

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Please sit down.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: You’re gonna sit here and I’m gonna go sit over there.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Please, sit yourself down.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: What, Michael.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Because nothing did, Michael.  It, I’m not going to say anything more about it, and I would advise that you do the same

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: No, Dwight; come in.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Is this how you’ve been conducting all the reviews, Michael?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Look, I know it’s your job, I know you have to ask, but I promise you, I’m not gonna discuss it with him, I’m certainly not gonna discuss it with you.  [digs a cigarette out of her purse] Do you have a light?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: I’m heading back to New York; Alan and I will conduct your performance review over the phone tomorrow.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Michael, now is not the time or the place.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: No, I am saying we are never having this conversation.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Never, for me, always means ‘never ever ever.’

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Michael, it has nothing-

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: With your looks, ok?  It’s your personality.  I mean, you’re obnoxious, and rude, and, and, and stupid, and you do have coffee breath, by the way, and, and I don’t agree about the b.o., but you are very, very inconsiderate.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Really.  You’re, you’re, you’re a great guy, ok?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: And you were very sweet, and you stayed up with me and talked with me, cried with me, and I appreciate that-

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: At this time in my life.  I just am not in the place right now where I’m looking for a relationship, so we can still work together, we can still be friends but… ok?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Ohhh, God.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: I am not going to discuss anything with you other than Dunder Mifflin business.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Period.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Do we understand each other?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Okay, let me make something clear. As embarrassing as this is, I feel that it needs to be said. There is nothing romantic or sexual going on with Michael and myself.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: The other night, I gave him a polite congratulatory kiss because he just closed the biggest deal of his career. And that’s it. If anything else has been implied, Dwight, or inferred, Michael, Creed, it’s just not true, okay? It’s not true. So… Is everyone straight on that?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Never for me always means never, ever, ever.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: What?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: What did you say, Michael?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Did you call my ex?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Gould, you said, Gould.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: How dare you, Michael? My personal life is off-limits to you.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Okay, how dare you do that?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Why would he do that? Why would he call you, Michael? Why would my husband call you?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: I mean…

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Hello, Michael.

quotes.text: Can we come in?

quotes.text: Thank you very much.

quotes.text: Oh, really? A surprise visit from his boss?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: A booze cruise? What do you mean?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Michael, we discussed the IRS’s regulations.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Okay, this event has to have legitimate business content to be tax deductible.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: We discussed that.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Good. This is Brenda Matlow from corporate training.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: I thought she could attend tonight, and if your event is appropriate, you could give it to other branches.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Brenda.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Okay, you know, I’m gonna go now, and…

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Good luck, Brenda.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Okay, see you later. And try to be professional.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: No, that’s all right.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: You call me if you need anything, Brenda.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: So, I’m happy to be here.  It’s very nice to see all of you. You’re all looking well.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Women today, though we have the same options as men, we often face a very different set of obstacles in getting there. So…

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Michael… I thought we agreed you wouldn’t be here.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: What are you doing?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Michael.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Michael.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: You are not allowed in this session.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Now you’re really not allowed in this session.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: I’m your boss.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: We’re fine, Michael. We just need you to leave, please.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Ladies, I am so, so sorry. Can we start again? We were on such a roll. I… I… really apologize.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Yes, Pam?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Michael!

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: [in the background] So one obstacle is how assertiveness is perceived differently in men and women. Men who are assertive will be admired. They’re called… anyone?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: I don’t know what you’re doing here, Michael,

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: … but it’s very destructive.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Can you please do this somewhere else, Michael?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Dwight, excellent idea. Go to the warehouse.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: I’m so sorry about that… um… so where were we? Pam, are you okay taking notes then?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Please? Thank you. very much.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Why don’t we go around the table and all say something that we know we’re good at. I will start. I am good at public speaking.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Great. Phyllis?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: No. Okay. Stop. Go on…

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: That is an excellent goal.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Great! Uh-huh?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Well, I’ll be honest. One of the goals of these women seminars is to feel out if there’s any standouts. Women who could be a valuable addition to our Corporate life.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Great, great. And Pam, what about you? What is your dream?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: You know the company is offering a design training program in New York.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Well, it’s only on weekends and then a few weeks in New York, but I’m sure that I could ask Corporate to help you out.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: There are always a million reasons not to do something.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: All right. Let’s talk about clothing.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Dress for the job you want, not the job you have. All right. You can use your clothing to send a message about your ambitions by wearing clothes that reflect what you aspire to be.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Another issue is inequality of pay between men and women. I’m sure that all of you have felt that before…

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: What? A union! What…

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: I’m not…

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: The cons are that everyone will lose their job. Michael. Everyone. Office, Warehouse. What do you think… the… pros… are… here?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: You got yourself into this Michael, so you get yourself out.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: That’s too bad.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: I don’t want to…

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Michael! Michael! Michael!

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Michael.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Don’t say another word.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Get yourself down stairs.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Sports metaphors are one of the ways women feel left out of the language of the office. Now, I know this might sound silly but a … many women ask to go over it. So… Fumble means…

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Right. Par for the course is a golf term. It means right on track. Below par means worse. Wait… that should mean better, that doesn’t make sense.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Excuse me?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: I don’t know what Michael was talking about. I don’t know.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: [in the background] Kelly, I don’t know what Michael’s talking about.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: I’m divorced.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: It was. Yes.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: I think you should all spend a little more time thinking about your careers and less time on personal stuff.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Okay. Let’s take five. I think we can all use five.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Did you take care of the situation?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Excuse me.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Excuse me. I’ve been told there’s been some interest in forming a Union and that Michael supported it. Obviously he’s not a friend of yours because he didn’t tell you the facts. So let me. If there is even a whiff of unionizing in this branch, I can guarantee you the branch will be shut down like that [snaps her fingers]. They unionized in Pittsfield and we all know what happened in Pittsfield. It will cost each of you a fortune in legal fees and union dues and that will be nothing compared to the cost of losing your jobs. So I would think long and hard before sacrificing your savings and your futures just to send a message. If you have any further questions you can direct them to… to Michael.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Josh Porter, Stamford.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: And Michael Scott, Scranton.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Fine Michael. Thank you.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Nervous, no I’m not nervous. Well, I guess I’d be lying if I didn’t say I was a little nervous. Umm, the new CFO is judging me on this too, and well, it is Michael, so. Yeah, I’m very nervous.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: OK. [looks toward Craig] Craig,

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Um, I’m sorry, what did you think financial presentation meant?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Craig, you realize that we’re trying to decide whether if drastic steps need to be taken?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Well, the point is, is that doesn’t exactly bode well for your branch.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: NO, NO I’m not, I’m not, I just… I just don’t know what to do anymore, Michael. I mean, we’re all gonna get fired.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Yeah, Michael – the CFO thinks that we slept together. Do you understand, people get fired for much less? And I just [scratches head] can’t believe that you told everybody and we didn’t even sleep together.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Oh, God. Michael. It was months ago. It was once, It’s over. Do you understand?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Surely, you cannot be serious?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Uh, that’s fine. Let’s just forget it.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Oh, Michael. Thank you again for that, really. It was very nice.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Oh, no, it’s OK. [Puts hand in way of elevator door to stop from closing.] So, uh, Happy valentine’s Day.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Oh.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Hello, Michael.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: I’m… returning your call, you said it was urgent.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Well, today’s not my birthday, so…

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: …Happy birthday, Michael.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Am I on camera?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: [on the phone] Michael, I’m gonna get going. I really don’t think I need to be in this meeting.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: [on phone] Yeah, but… Well, the fact of the matter is that your branch is currently number four of the five branches that I oversee.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Michael?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: You know that I’m very serious here.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: What?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: I thought that you were their fearless leader.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: [laughs] I think you can handle it.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: I think so, Michael…

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Goodbye, Michael.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Michael?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: You know, I… I thought about it and you are right.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: I could use a little fun. So, I am going to drive up for your Casino Night.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Incidentally, what is the charity?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Okay, then. I will see you tonight.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Bye-bye.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Michael?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Hi.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: What are you… Just… Wait, what’re you talking about?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: No. No, you didn’t. Hi, I’m Jan. I’m Michael’s boss.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Does anyone want a drink?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Okay. [Carol stares at Michael]

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Cosmopolitan, please.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Well, it’s part of the job, you know? Keep an eye on things. So… Why not? So, how long have you and Michael been…

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Casino Night in the warehouse. Good sport.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Oh, me too. Me too.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: What?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: No, I…

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: I didn’t… I don’t know…

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Smoke?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Fabulous time. I drove two and a half hours to get here.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Left work early, drove down here. And I am completely underdressed

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Why did I hook up with Michael?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: It was very late, Jim. Very… Very late and… Have you given any more thought to the transfer?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Good. Have you told anyone?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Well, you should.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Hey. I’m leaving.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: So, I just wanted to congratulate you on a fantastic evening. You did the company proud.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: And thanks for inviting me. You were right, I needed it. So, thanks.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Nice to meet you.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: And you guys have a good time together.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Yeah.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: You know, it’s amazing to me that in this day and age, you could be so obtuse about sexual orientation.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: That’s not what it’s called.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Coming out, is a significant moment for a gay person, and they should be allowed to select the timing and manner of announcing it.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: NO!

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: No, it’s not possible.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: You know, imagine… you were gay.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Michael, your immaturity is extremely disappointing and may even lead to a lawsuit which is the absolute last thing this company needs right now.  Do you understand?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: [on speakerphone] Okay, what is your goal for after lunch?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: [under breath] Heaven help us. [aloud] Specifically.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Specifically, Michael.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: [on speakerphone] Are you on the toilet, Michael?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Well, I know sometimes you are and… that you wouldn’t tell me, so I’m just going to assume that you are, and call me back when you’re finished.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Oh, hey!

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: We all checked in?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Great, let’s dump our stuff and meet back here in half an hour.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Okay!

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: What are you talking about?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Step away from me, Michael.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Great!

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: What have you generated, Michael?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: What party?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Michael, um… Jim and Josh are in meetings all day. And I am in and out of meetings. I can’t stay on top of you 24/7.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Really?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Well, Michael, I underestimated you.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: [Jim, Josh, and Jan walk in the hotel lobby] Josh, um… [Jim continues walking ahead] Why don’t you come up to my room for a couple of minutes and we can just go over the schedule for tomorrow together.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: A quick drink?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: [putting on a good face] Great! [walks off]

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: [walking into an empty office because everyone is watching Varsity Blues] Hello?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Hello? [Angela coughs and points to the conference room]

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: How would a movie increase productivity Michael?  How on earth would it do that?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Magically?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: No.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: [answering the phone] Hello?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Who is this?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: You should talk to Michael, and he’ll talk to me, and that way we don’t have to speak to each other.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: What about him?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: It’s not about a surprise party is it?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Look, I am already an hour outside of Scranton, Dwight, I’m not coming back.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: How do you know I like that store?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: How do you know that?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: No it’s not.  It’s officially not.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Yeah.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Really?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Ok.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: What would you do differently?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Dwight, you must feel strongly, to speak with me this way, behind Michael’s back, and turn on so many of your co-workers.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: [thinks for a second] Where is it?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: [on speakerphone with Michael] Michael.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: I just had a very interesting conversation with one of your employees.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: No, it wasn’t.  Dwight just told me that he thinks he can run the branch better than you.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Mm-hmm.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: You can’t have people undermining you.  Get control of your branch immediately.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Hey, Jim?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: How’s work going?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: [kills Jim’s character, giggles] Oh, you know what, I gotta see Josh right now, but remind me to tell you what Dwight said to me earlier, okay? You’ll get a big kick out of it. [leaves]

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: [on speakerphone] So, I wanted to let you know that we lost Ed Truck.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Michael, Ed died over the weekend.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: [on speakerphone] I understand how you feel, Michael.  I really do.  So, would it be helpful to give everyone the day off?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Well, what would you suggest?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Of Ed?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: [scoffs] I’m not sure that’s realistic.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: No, that’s not—

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: What the hell are you two talking about?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: You know what, Michael?  I’ve really tried with you today…

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: …and I have to get back to work.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: So call me when you feel like having a real conversation.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Goodbye. [hangs up]

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: [on the phone] Ed Truck died over the weekend.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Yeah. And I know… I know he was your boss, so I thought you should know.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Yes, they know, Michael.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: I guess, yes. I think it would be appropriate for you to make an announcement to your team, in case they want to pay their respects.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Good.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Tell me what you did yesterday.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Nothing?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: I don’t care how your day was Michael.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Tell me what you did yesterday.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Hi, Pam.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: I’m great. So, Pam I would like you to keep a log of everything Michael does hour by hour so we can analyze it at corporate. Ok?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Thanks Pam.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: What I want, Michael, is an hour-by-hour log of how you spend your work time.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Zoning out?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: If you can account for your time…

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: …then maybe corporate can justify your salary.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Michael, what is this about you letting everyone leave work early today?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: What is Diwali?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Yes.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Mich—

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Oh.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Oh.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Yes, of course, I know Kelly.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: I thought she was Muslim.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Well, I think it sounds lovely. I think it sounds like a good idea.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Yes, of course. It’s important to celebrate our company’s rich diversity. And, and in fact, Michael, if you had planned better, we might have been able to charter a bus to the event—

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: —or, or, or been a sponsor for the party itself.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Hey, one person is an integral part of the fabric—

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Michael.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Michael.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Michael.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: I am here to tell you that we are closing the Scranton branch.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: The board voted last night to close your branch.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: The board’s.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: I’m very sorry. I don’t relish telling you this. You’ve been a big part of this company, and the board asked me to thank you for your years of service.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: A small number of people will be transferred to the Stamford branch, and the rest will be getting severance packages.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Well, we haven’t made final decisions about personnel yet. But you’re a severance package person.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Well, it’s not all about numbers, Michael.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: It’s… it’s about talent.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Our CFO believes that Josh is going to play an important role in our company’s future.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Hi.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Oh, good. You’re both here. Ready to talk logistics?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: So, Josh will be running what is now called Dunder-Mifflin ,Northeast, which is all the offices north of Stamford. And Jim, fi you want the job, you’ll be his number two.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Awesome.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Wha… excuse… why not?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Today?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: You leveraged your new position with us into another offer?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Damn it, Josh. This whole restructuring thing was based around keeping you. I…

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: I’m gonna make some calls.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: So… we are still scrambling here. But uh, it looks like Scranton is going to absorb Stamford.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: And I know that you just left there a couple of months ago, but we would like to offer you the number two position at that branch.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Yeah.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Michael.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Ah. Well, please think about it. And call me. We will do whatever we can to get you to stay.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: [in Scranton] Where’s Michael?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: [looks around, noticing that no one is working] Wha… what’s going on here?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Ah, god. Okay. You know what everybody? I’m sure there is a better way to do this but I’ve drive something like 400 miles today and I’m completely exhausted so I’m just gonna tell you. Your branch is not closing; Stamford is closing. Um, for the time being, it seems that all your jobs are safe.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Well, reasons are not important. Would you just call him, please? Wherever he is… and tell him.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Back?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Uh, we don’t know. Probably. A few.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Michael!

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Did you fire Tony Gardner when he was trying to quit?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Do you realize, Michael, that we now have to pay him severance?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: You do?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: What? No. No. No, Jim is your Number Two.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: He’s the only one  who has worked with both groups. I sent you a memo about this.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: [over phone] Mmhmm.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: We get that money for hiring an ex-convict.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: When did the check come?

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Okay, that’s when the branches merged, so Josh must have been taking advantage of this program. Smart move.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: Uh, reformed convict, and, uh, I’m not sure. Though hang on, let me email our HR, stay on the line.

quotes.speaker: Jan
quotes.text: …Okay it’s someone named Martin Nash.

quotes.text: Michael?

quotes.text: Hey, you big queen.

quotes.text: Hey, is old Godzillary coming in today?

quotes.speaker: Todd Packer
quotes.text: [on the phone] Is this Michael Scott? My secret lover. My intercom, I told you never to call me here. Never! [Michael’s laughing]

quotes.text: [on the phone] Bergerstein!

quotes.speaker: Todd Packer
quotes.text: [on the phone] Bergerstein!

quotes.speaker: Todd Packer
quotes.text: [on the phone] I want my money back you greedy Hebrew. Bergerstein!

quotes.speaker: Todd Packer
quotes.text: [sounds sick on the phone] I can’t make it.

quotes.speaker: Todd Packer
quotes.text: [on the phone] I… I’m not coming.

quotes.speaker: Todd Packer
quotes.text: [on the phone] Oh, God! Stop whining. You know, you only come to the pick up game once a year. You little bitch. [Michael picks up phone, takes it off speakerphone] All right, yup. Hey, okay. No problem, you know, best you can do. Hey, you know. Hey, nice talking to you too. All right take care. [sighs] Michael Scoot. That’s funny. He’s a good friend.

quotes.speaker: Todd Packer
quotes.text: What has two thumbs and likes to bone your Mom? [points at self] This guy!

quotes.speaker: Todd Packer
quotes.text: [makes laser gun noises]

quotes.speaker: Todd Packer
quotes.text: bleep, bleep. What’s up, Halpert?

quotes.speaker: Todd Packer
quotes.text: Still queer?

quotes.speaker: Todd Packer
quotes.text: Are you kidding? Everyone knows why! You don’t know? Okay, check this out. Al lright. So here’s the story. So Randall is nailing his secretary, right? And she is totally incompetent.

quotes.text: Like 10 words a minute… talking.

quotes.speaker: Todd Packer
quotes.text: They are women, right?

quotes.speaker: Todd Packer
quotes.text: I said it. And then, suddenly, for no reason, this bimbo blows the whistle on the whole thing just to be a bitch.

quotes.speaker: Todd Packer
quotes.text: Meant to ask you, can you think you can get someone to drive me around because of the, uh, DUI situation?

quotes.text: [to Ryan] Come on, kid. Let’s go.

quotes.speaker: Todd Packer
quotes.text: Why does everyone ask me that? Who the hell is that?

quotes.speaker: Todd Packer
quotes.text: Don’t ever let this little bitch drive you around town. We got, uh, lost for half an hour.

quotes.speaker: Todd Packer
quotes.text: Where is Michael Snot? Sniffing some dude’s thong? Probably.

quotes.speaker: Todd Packer
quotes.text: There he is.

quotes.speaker: Todd Packer
quotes.text: There he is. Good one.

quotes.speaker: Todd Packer
quotes.text: So a guy goes home, tells his wife, “Honey. Pack your bags. I just won the lottery.” She goes, “Oh my god! That’s incredible! Where are we going?” He goes, “I don’t know where you’re going, just be out of here by five!” [men laugh] Boom!

quotes.speaker: Todd Packer
quotes.text: There’s this guy. He’s at a Nymphomaniac Convention. And he is psyched ’cause all these women are smokin’ hot perfect 10’s, except for this one chick who looks a lot like, uh… [points at Phyllis]

quotes.text: [rapping] What’s up my nerds. Check it out. [points at the mistletoe stuck down his pants]

quotes.text: Hello, yes. I’m looking for a gay nerd named Michael Scott.

quotes.text: What?

quotes.text: Well, uh, for decorations, maybe we could… it’s stupid, forget it.

quotes.text: Yeah?

quotes.speaker: Phyllis
quotes.text: Well, there’s green, um, blue… yellow… red…

quotes.text: Oh, boy… You…

quotes.text: I have a sports bra.

quotes.text: I’ll do it.

quotes.text: Live and learn.

quotes.text: [whispering] It’s about Michael.

quotes.text: Dwight, get out of here!!

quotes.speaker: Phyllis
quotes.text: What were you doing in the ladies room?!

quotes.speaker: Phyllis
quotes.text: Why were you peering over the stalls?!

quotes.speaker: Phyllis
quotes.text: You are a pervert!

quotes.speaker: Phyllis
quotes.text: You, are, a pervert!

quotes.text: But where would we…go?

quotes.speaker: Phyllis
quotes.text: This says “Bushiest Beaver”.

quotes.speaker: Phyllis
quotes.text: It’s, it’s fine.

quotes.speaker: Phyllis
quotes.text: Dwight, get out of here!

quotes.speaker: Phyllis
quotes.text: You can’t be in here!

quotes.speaker: Phyllis
quotes.text: Shut up. You’re a freak!

quotes.speaker: Phyllis
quotes.text: You are…

quotes.speaker: Phyllis
quotes.text: I’m telling Michael.

quotes.speaker: Phyllis
quotes.text: I’m telling Michael.

quotes.speaker: Phyllis
quotes.text: Michael, Michael.

quotes.speaker: Phyllis
quotes.text: Dwight was in the ladies’ room and he was looking at me.

quotes.speaker: Phyllis
quotes.text: He was looking at me in the ladies’ room.

quotes.speaker: Phyllis
quotes.text: That’s what I said. He was spying in the ladies’ room.

quotes.speaker: Phyllis
quotes.text: Write him up or I’ll take it to Jan.

quotes.speaker: Phyllis
quotes.text: All right.

quotes.speaker: Phyllis
quotes.text: All relationships? Eh, even a one-night stand?

quotes.text: I’m the same age as you, Michael.

quotes.speaker: Phyllis

quotes.speaker: Phyllis
quotes.text: Michael! Come on!

quotes.speaker: Phyllis
quotes.text: You don’t have to worry. I’m not going to…

quotes.text: I’ll do it.

quotes.text: Are you calling me a ho?

quotes.text: What do you mean?

quotes.text: No.

quotes.text: Oh, you say that every time.

quotes.text: Oh, boy…

quotes.text: Um, The DaVinci Code.

quotes.text: Definitely Jim.

quotes.text: Come on, Pam.

quotes.speaker: Phyllis
quotes.text: Yeah, I like Oscar.

quotes.text: What are you? A monk?

quotes.speaker: Phyllis
quotes.text: Ass.

quotes.text: Mmm-hmm.

quotes.text: They’re important.

quotes.text: First message is:

quotes.speaker: Phyllis
quotes.text: Do you think they’ll get the account. [Stanley stares at her] How come you never answer me?

quotes.text: Does he die?

quotes.speaker: Phyllis
quotes.text: Sure.

quotes.speaker: Phyllis
quotes.text: You tell me.  Well, you do mean you and Jim right?  Oh God.  I am so sorry, I thought, you guys hang out all the time and you’re talking all the time.  I’m sorry!

phyllis.summary: Phyllis is also a Dunder Mifflin salesperson. While Phyllis is typically very laid back and quiet she is very protective of her position in the company and her sales commissions.

stanley.summary: Stanley is a fairly successful salesman who resents spending time in an office where he typically is not productive. Stanley tolerates Michael's long and typically pointless conference room meetings by spending his time completing crossword puzzles.
stanley.name: Stanley Hudson

quotes.speaker: Angela
quotes.text: When Michael suggested canceling Christmas, I was outraged, not on my behalf, but on behalf of baby Jesus. I mean, would he cancel Christmas because he got dumped or he was two weeks behind on his party planning, on top of the fact that his cats were ill? I think not. I think baby Jesus would suck it up and plan his party.

angela.summary: Angela is one of the lead accountants in The Office who has a tremendous affection for cats and tends to be a bit judgmental. Her no nonsense approach to how things should be done in the office appeals to Dwight.

kevin.summary: Kevin is the third accountant in the office and he is less adept at accounting than one might expect. Kevin was given his job by Michael despite being under qualified and that helps to explain why he occasionally becomes confused about fairly simple concepts.
kevin.name: Kevin Malone

ryan.summary: Ryan Howard is a temporary employee in season one but eventually gets promoted to be Michael’s supervisor at Dunder Mifflin.

toby.summary: Toby is the head of human resources and he and Michael do not get along well. Toby frequently tries (with little success) to prevent Michael from violating corporate policy. As a result, Michael develops a strong grudge against Toby.
toby.name: Toby Flenderson

So now I’m doing this new thing where I just leave piles of clothes on the floor and then I walk around the piles to get an outfit…

kelly.summary: Kelly Kapoor is in charge of customer relations at Dunder Mifflin Scranton. She is a very competent employee but she is extremely talkative and a bit of a gossip. She enjoys talking about trivial matters such as celebrity gossip and could certainly be accused of being obsessed about getting married (particularly to her on again off again boyfriend Ryan).
kelly.name: Kelly Kapoor

creed.summary: Creed is ostensibly in charge of quality control for Dunder Mifflin paper. Creed is a highly unusual among the employees of Dunder Mifflin, showing a questionable history and affiliation with a complete lack of morals.

quotes.speaker: Andy
quotes.text: So she looks really hot, so I said, “You look hotter than usual today.” [to waitress] Thank you. Michael [gesturing to sit down.] Head of the table.

quotes.speaker: Andy
quotes.text: So she looks at me right, and she goes, “I’m sorry, don’t I even know you?” After a year, a year of buying lattes from her, do you believe that?

quotes.speaker: Andy
quotes.text: No.

quotes.speaker: Andy
quotes.text: Put that away. Put that away. S.O.S. We… I… May day. Haha. Man down over here, [to waitress] we need your help.

quotes.speaker: Andy
quotes.text: I think we’ll start with a round of noga-sakes. [waitress gives confused look]

quotes.speaker: Andy
quotes.text: One part eggnog, three parts sake. Some places won’t make it for you though, because eggnog is seasonal.

quotes.speaker: Andy
quotes.text: Wait for the onion. Trust me. Hey Cindy, he just had his heart broken, you wouldn’t do that to him, would you?

quotes.speaker: Andy
quotes.text: You made her laugh. Yes! She totally digs us. [referring to what chef is doing] Watch, watch, watch, watch. [Onions smoke up] Heh, heh? What did I tell ‘ya?

quotes.speaker: Andy
quotes.text: This drink… [in audible conversation with Michael]

quotes.speaker: Andy
quotes.text: Cindy, Cindy.

quotes.speaker: Andy
quotes.text: I want you to close your eyes and imagine your dream house. [Cindy laughs] C’mon, do it for Michael. He’s had a really long day.

quotes.speaker: Andy
quotes.text: This is great.

quotes.speaker: Andy
quotes.text: Now open your eyes and describe it to me.

quotes.speaker: Andy
quotes.text: [referring to waitresses] They have been checking us out, all night! I am not kidding!

quotes.speaker: Andy
quotes.text: What?

quotes.speaker: Andy
quotes.text: Now, you are thinking. Yes. And you know what? Because you have had such a rough day, you get Cindy.

quotes.speaker: Andy
quotes.text: My new girlfriend.

quotes.speaker: Andy
quotes.text: Your hands.

quotes.speaker: Andy
quotes.text: I’ll use my hands on it.

andy.summary: Andy joined the sales staff at Dunder Mifflin after spending time at the Stamford Branch before it was closed due to downsizing. Andy did later become manager of Dunder Mifflin for a time, but for most of the series he acts as a salesman. His early appearances displayed him as a one-upping suckup employee with a tendency to loose one's temper. Andy is also unusually talented when it comes to singing, often boasting of his education at Cornell University in a capella group.
andy.name: Andy Bernard

quotes.speaker: Karen
quotes.text: We didn’t have a party planning committee in Stamford. Somebody would just volunteer to run out to Carvel and pick up an ice cream cake. So the fact that they have a committee here, fascinating.
